details.title: The availability of inspected systems subject to shocks and graceful degradation

kwd: s-independent and identically distributed random variables

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng., Texas A&M Univ., College Station, TX, USA

p: Georgia-Ann Klutke is Professor of Industrial Engineering at Texas A&M University and Director of the TEES Institute of Manufacturing Systems at Texas A&M. She received her B.S. in mathematics, M.S. in biostatistics from the University of Michigan, and Ph.D. in industrial engineering and operations research from the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University. Her research interests are in the applications of probability to production operations, including equipment reliability and maintenance.

authors.name: G.-A. Klutke

p: Yoonjung Yang is a Research Engineer with the Supply Chain Management Command Center at Samsung Electronics in Seoul, Korea. She received her B.S. in mathematics education from Seoul National University, and M.S. and Ph.D. in industrial engineering from Texas A&M University. Her research interests include applied probability, maintenance science, and supply chain management.

details.abstract: This paper studies maintained systems with nonself-announcing ("hidden") failures that deteriorate due to both shocks and graceful degradation. Shocks occur according to a Poisson process, shock magnitudes are i.d.d. random variables, and between shocks, deterioration occurs at a constant rate. Inspections are performed periodically. Using regenerative arguments, an expression is derived for limiting average availability. This expression provides insight into the effect of system life distribution on availability, and suggests opportunities for more effective inspection strategies.

references.title: Non-stationary shock models

context.text: There is a long history of research on shock degradation models [1], [2], [7], [8], and on the closely related topic of modeling “delayed symptoms of failure,” [11], [13], but these papers address only self-announcing failures.

references.text: M. Abdel-Hameed, F. Proschan, "Non-stationary shock models", Stochastic Processes and Their Applications, vol. 1, pp. 383-404, 1973.

references.text: M. Abdel-Hameed, I. N. Shimi, "Optimal replacement of damaged devices", J. Applied Probability, vol. 15, pp. 153-161, 1978.

references.title: An approach for computing tight numerical bounds on renewal functions

context.text: The numerator of (10) yields readily to recent numerical techniques for computing renewal-type functions [4].

links.abstract: This method computes tight lower and upper bounds for the renewal function. It is based on Riemann-Stieltjes integration, and provides bounds for solving certain renewal equations used in the study of availability. An error analysis is given for the numerical bounds when inter-renewal time distributions are sufficiently smooth. Three examples are explored that demonstrate the accuracy of these computed numerical bounds.

references.text: H. Ayhan, J. Limon-Robles, M. A. Wortman, "An approach for computing tight numerical bounds on renewal functions", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 48, pp. 182-188, 1998.

references.title: Optimum checking procedures

context.text: Several authors, dating back to [5], have studied the problem of developing effective maintenance policies for systems that evolve randomly.

references.text: R. E. Barlow, L. C. Hunter, F. Proschan, "Optimum checking procedures", SIAM J., vol. 11, no. 4, pp. 1078-1095, 1963.

references.title: Shock models and wear processes

references.title: A cumulative damage shock model with imperfect preventive maintenance

context.text: There is a long history of research on shock degradation models [1], [2], [7], [8], and on the closely related topic of modeling “delayed symptoms of failure,” [11], [13], but these papers address only self-announcing failures.

references.text: M. Kijima, T. Nakagawa, "A cumulative damage shock model with imperfect preventive maintenance", Naval Research Logistics, vol. 38, pp. 145-156, 1991.

references.title: The availability of inspected systems subject to random deterioration

context.text: Reference [9] considered this problem under the assumption that the system degrades according to a random but continuous (graceful) deterioration process.
Using techniques quite different from those in [9], [15] computes the system availability and shows that among renewal inspection policies, periodic inspections are best.
This paper analyzes a model that incorporates a more general deterioration process than either [9] or [15]: the process includes both shock degradation and graceful degradation.
Neither the approach of [9] nor that of [15], extends in a straightforward fashion to include both types of degradation.

references.text: G.-A. Klutke, M. A. Wortman, H. Ayhan, "The availability of inspected systems subject to random deterioration", Probability in the Engineering and Informational Sciences, vol. 10, pp. 109-118, 1996.

references.title: Optimum inspection policies for a standby unit

context.text: Only a few papers address nonself-announcing failures, [10], [12], [16], which consider inspecting standby systems.

links.abstract: Optimum preventive maintenance policies are discussed to maximize the availability for a 2-unit standby redundant system. The Laplace-Stieltjes transform of the pointwise availability and the steady-state availability are derived by applying a unique modification of the regeneration point techniques under the assumptions that all the distributions are arbitrary. A theorem gives the optimum preventive maintenance time which is a unique and finite solution of the equation under certain conditions....

references.text: T. Nakagawa, "Optimum inspection policies for a standby unit", J. Operations Research Society of Japan, vol. 23, pp. 13-26, 1980.

references.text: G. Parmigiani, "On optimal screening ages", J. American Statistical Assoc., vol. 88, pp. 622-628, 1993.

references.text: G. Parmigiani, "Inspection times for standby units", J. Applied Probability, vol. 31, pp. 1015-1025, 1994.

references.title: A maintenance strategy for systems subjected to deterioration governed by random shocks

context.text: Reference [15] considers the case where inspections are made according to a (stationary) renewal process and the system degrades due to random shocks.
Using techniques quite different from those in [9], [15] computes the system availability and shows that among renewal inspection policies, periodic inspections are best.
This paper analyzes a model that incorporates a more general deterioration process than either [9] or [15]: the process includes both shock degradation and graceful degradation.
Neither the approach of [9] nor that of [15], extends in a straightforward fashion to include both types of degradation.

links.abstract: The authors examine the time-stationary availability of maintained systems that deteriorate according to a random-shock process. System failures are not self-announcing; hence, failures must be detected via inspection. The approach considers randomly occurring shocks that cumulatively damage the system; shock magnitudes are taken as random. The authors develop an expression for computing system availability when inspections follow a renewal process. This expression leads to a proved proposition ...

references.text: M. A. Wortman, G.-A. Klutke, H. Ayhan, "A maintenance strategy for systems subjected to deterioration governed by random shocks", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 43, no. 3, pp. 439-445, 1994.

references.title: An optimal inspection-repair-replacement policy for standby systems

context.text: Only a few papers address nonself-announcing failures, [10], [12], [16], which consider inspecting standby systems.
Reference [16] considers the case where repairs bring the system to a “bad-as-old” state.

references.text: L. Yeh, "An optimal inspection-repair-replacement policy for standby systems", J. Applied Probability, vol. 32, pp. 212-223, 1995.
